questions.question_text: Which two physical resources are abstracted by the hypervisor and presented to virtual machines? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
CPU and Memory are the physical ressources

Selected Answer: BE
The two main physical resources abstracted by the hypervisor and presented to virtual machines are:

CPU (Central Processing Unit): The hypervisor abstracts the physical CPU cores of the host machine and presents them as virtual CPU cores to each virtual machine. Virtual CPUs (vCPUs) allow multiple virtual machines to share the physical CPU resources efficiently. The hypervisor manages the scheduling and allocation of CPU time among the virtual machines to ensure fair access and optimal performance.

Memory (RAM): The hypervisor abstracts the physical memory (RAM) of the host machine and partitions it into virtual memory segments allocated to each virtual machine. Each virtual machine operates within its allocated memory space, isolated from other virtual machines running on the same host. The hypervisor manages memory allocation and ensures that each virtual machine has sufficient memory to execute its tasks without contention.

Selected Answer: BE
The two physical resources that are abstracted by the hypervisor and presented to virtual machines are:

B. CPU
E. Memory

The hypervisor abstracts physical CPU cores and memory (RAM) from the underlying physical hardware and presents these resources to virtual machines. This abstraction allows multiple virtual machines to share the physical CPU and memory while operating as if they have dedicated access to these resources. This abstraction and sharing of CPU and memory enable the consolidation of multiple workloads onto a single physical server without the need for each virtual machine to have its own dedicated hardware.

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to separate traffic of virtual machine live migrations from all other traffic.
Which TCP/IP stack meets this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
VMware's vMotion TCP/IP stack is specifically designed to handle live migration traffic, which includes moving virtual machines (VMs) between physical hosts with no interruption to the VM's availability. This TCP/IP stack ensures that vMotion traffic is efficiently managed and prioritized, separate from other network traffic to ensure optimal performance and reliability during migration operations.

Selected Answer: B
vMotion

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B. vMotion is used for powered-on VM migration and Provisioning is used for powered-off VMs.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is concerned that a VM has high ballooning activity and needs to check the default display of the Advanced Performance pane in the vSphere
Client to confirm this activity.
Which view should the administrator choose in the default display?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Ballooning = memory reclamation

Selected Answer: D
Virtual memory ballooning is a memory reclamation technique used by a hypervisor, when it runs low on RAM memory, to allow the physical host system to retrieve unused memory from some guest virtual machines (VMs) and share it with others mainly.

Selected Answer: D
To check high ballooning activity for a VM in the default display of the Advanced Performance pane in the vSphere Client, the view the administrator should choose is:

D. Memory

The Memory view within the Advanced Performance pane provides information and metrics related to memory usage and performance for virtual machines. Ballooning is a memory reclamation technique used by VMware when the host is under memory pressure. Monitoring the Memory view can help administrators identify and analyze memory-related issues, including ballooning activity, to understand how memory resources are being utilized by the VMs.
